Description.val: The MQ-8 Vertical Take-Off and Landing Tactical Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (popular name "Fire Scout") provides real-time and non-real-time Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance data to tactical users without the use of manned aircraft or reliance on limited joint theater or national assets. This line item funds correction of deficiencies, modernization, modification of payloads, mission systems, ship control stations and retrofit of systems/avionics realized as a result of obsolescence and engineering change orders.  This is a FY2014 new start that aligns to the MQ-8 Initial Operational Capability and deployment of Rapid Deployment Capability aircraft.

Justification.val: Support correction of deficiencies found during operational use and deployments, improvements for maintainability and reliability, special payloads, emerging requirements, and concurrency in MQ-8C development and production.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiences and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Title.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiences and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Name.val: 2.1.1) Installation Equipment - Hot Weather Mods - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: The FY 2016 cost increase results from more expensive weapons replaceable assemblies and components being replaced due to obsolescence.

Name.val: 2.2.1) Installation Equipment - Hot Weather Mods - Organic

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) will provide capability to operate in hot temperature environments, improve system performance, reliability and maintainability of sensors, avionics and airframe components, and provide broader sensors for Intelligence, Surveillance, & Reconnaissance (ISR) collection for both Navy and urgent operational requirements. Weather mods will be Depot Level, performed at Fleet Readiness Centers (FRCs). These are structural modifications to access panels (vents added), modification of belly panel (depot removal and modification), installation of vent and access door on tailboom, structural modification of inside of sponson to install larger cooling fan. 
This OSIP will also correct deficiencies resulting from obsolescence and diminishing manufacturing resources. These components include, but are not limited to, the Vehicle Management Computer, Payloads Interface Unit, the Ground Control Station's Real Time Processor, and the Digital Control Processor.
This OSIP will also support Payload mods which will be Depot level, performed at FRCs. Structural and wiring modifications for mounting and wiring provisions of additional payloads. Installation of the payloads themselves would be done at the O-level based on mission requirements. 

This OSIP supports MQ-8B and MQ-8C aircraft. Aircraft will be modified in FY14 to support obsolescence/reliability corrections, payloads and hot weather sustainment. Operational Requirements Document: Joint Requirements Oversight Council Memorandum 004-99, Joint Rapid Acquisition Cell Memorandum AF-0002.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability is FY14.  Ongoing MQ-8B deployments have occurred since FY10 to support the ISR Task Force and other Joint Urgent Operational Need and Urgent Operational Need requirements.  The first MQ-8C deployment providing Rapid Deployment Capabilities is planned for FY14.
